document.docAuthor: Boyko, Christopher B., Williams, Jason D. & Shields, Jeffrey D.
document.masterDocTitle: Parasites (Isopoda: Epicaridea and Nematoda) from ghost and mud shrimp (Decapoda: Axiidea and Gebiidea) with descriptions of a new genus and a new species of bopyrid isopod and clarification of Pseudione Kossmann, 1881

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Parasites (Isopoda: Epicaridea and Nematoda) from ghost and mud shrimp (Decapoda: Axiidea and Gebiidea) with descriptions of a new genus and a new species of bopyrid isopod and clarification of Pseudione Kossmann, 1881

figureCitation.captionText: FIGURE 4. Gyge ovalis (Shiino, 1939) (ZRC 1997.713) ex Austinogebia edulis Ngoc-Ho & Chan, 1992.A, immature female, dorsal view; B, male, dorsal view.Scale bars: A, B = 1.0 mm.

paragraph.materialsCitation:
Material examined
.
Taiwan :
Immature female ( 3.8 mm ), mature male ( 2.1 mm ), ex right branchial chamber of female
Austinogebia edulis
(8.0 mm CL), Yilan County , port at Tai-Chi , shallow water, coll. inland trawlers ( ZRC 2016.0440 )

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution . Japan , South Korea , Taiwan , and China .

Hosts .
Austinogebia edulis
(Ngoc-Ho & Chan, 1992),
A
. narutensis (Sakai, 1986)
,
A . wuhsienweni
(Yu, 1931)
,
Upogebia carinicauda (Stimpson, 1860)
,
U. issaeffi (Balss, 1913)
(possible type host),
U . major (De Haan, 1841)
(probable type host), and
U . yokoyai Makarov, 1938
.

Remarks . The host of the types was originally reported as
Upogebia major (De Haan, 1841) in Shiino (1939b)
but was changed to
U . issaeffi (Balss, 1913) in Shiino (1958)
and back again to
U . major in Shiino (1972)
. This species has been reported several times from
U . major
, including in a large-scale study of the host/parasite relationship by
Ubaldo et al . (2014)
, but only once subsequently from
U . issaeffi ( Itani 2004b )
. The identity of the type host is therefore most likely
U. major
, but only examination of the type host can solve this question. Markham (2004) included Codreanu (1941: 140) in his synonymy list under
Metabopyrus ovalis
, but nowhere in that paper is the species mentioned and there is no p. 140 in that article; the page was probably from Codreanu (1961) where the species is mentioned and the “1941” citation is therefore a lapsus for 1961.
Chapman et al . (2012)
incorrectly stated that the record of
Gyge ovalis
from Itani (2004b) was a misidentification of
Orthione griffenis Markham, 2004
. Itani’s (2004b) identification was correct, albeit under the original combination of
Metabopyrus ovalis
. The record in Itani’s (2004b) Table 3 that is referrable to
O . griffenis
is actually “ Pseudioninae sp. 1” (Williams & An 2009;
Itani et al . 2014
). The present record ( Fig. 4 ) is only the second from Taiwan and
A
. edulis
is the only known host in Taiwan .
